<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;25%</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">25%</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-size:1pt" BGCOLOR="#efefef">
<TD HEIGHT="5"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#efefef" STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">&lt; 25%</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">0%</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Compensation Committee believes that relative TSR is an important metric for the
Company&#146;s shareholders in evaluating the Company&#146;s performance against the performance of other companies. The use of relative TSR creates inherent alignment with shareholders&#146; interests, and the measurement process for calculating
relative TSR is simple and objective. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Frequency of Equity Awards and Impact on the Summary Compensation Table.</B>
As part of its review and redesign of the executive compensation program, the Compensation Committee reconsidered its prior practice of granting equity awards to executives, other than the CEO, approximately every two fiscal years. In consultation
with its independent compensation consultant about market practices and peer company data, the Compensation Committee decided to transition from biennial equity grants to annual grants starting in 2014. Starting in 2015, the Compensation Committee
expects to award the annual grants shortly after the beginning of each fiscal year. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Compensation Committee
considered market data on equity grant levels for the peer companies provided by its independent compensation consultant. The Compensation Committee also reviewed the mix of time-based and performance-based equity awards granted to executives at
peer companies and decided to allocate the awards granted in 2014 between 60% time-based and 40% performance-based awards, as a percentage of the grant date value reported in the Summary Compensation Table. After reviewing market compensation data
provided by its independent compensation consultant, the scope of responsibility assigned to each executive officer, the Company&#146;s historical equity grants, and the Company&#146;s financial results and market capitalization compared to peer
companies, the Compensation Committee determined that a total grant date value of $20 million for each executive officer, other than Mr.&nbsp;Cook and Mr.&nbsp;Oppenheimer, was appropriate for the 2014 annual award. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Regular Vesting Intervals Maximize Retention and Support Long-Term Focus. </B>The Company believes granting awards with regular
vesting intervals creates a substantial retention incentive and also encourages </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 33 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">
the named executive officers to focus on the Company&#146;s long-term business objectives and long-term stock price performance. The Compensation Committee has discretion to grant awards with
different vesting schedules to new hires or employees who are promoted to the executive team, and in special cases as determined by the Compensation Committee. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The time-based RSUs subject to Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s modified 2011 RSU award are scheduled to vest in annual installments until
August&nbsp;24, 2021, as demonstrated in the table above, subject to his continued employment with the Company through the applicable vesting date. The time-based RSUs granted to Mr.&nbsp;Cue and Mr.&nbsp;Williams on March&nbsp;3, 2014 are scheduled
to vest in three annual installments commencing April&nbsp;1, 2016, subject to each individual&#146;s continued employment with the Company through the applicable vesting date. The April vesting dates for the time-based RSUs were selected to balance
the October vesting dates for the performance-based RSUs and provide regular vesting intervals. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Dividend
Equivalents.</B> Dividend equivalents accrue on all unvested RSUs, other than RSUs held by Mr.&nbsp;Cook, and are paid out only upon the vesting of the underlying RSUs. The crediting of dividend equivalents is meant to preserve the equity-based
incentives intended by the Company when the awards were granted and to treat employees with RSU awards consistently with shareholders. The dividend equivalents on the performance-based RSUs are subject to the same performance conditions as the
underlying awards. At Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s request, his RSU awards do not include dividend equivalents. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>The Role of
Cash Compensation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Base Salaries.</B> Base salaries are customary and help attract and retain executives. In
February 2014, after reviewing peer company market data provided by its independent compensation consultant, the Compensation Committee increased Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s base salary from $1.4 million to $2 million and the base salaries of the other
executive officers from $875,000 to $1 million. This change was intended to recognize the responsibilities assigned to each officer and to maintain internal equity among the executive team. The Compensation Committee also considered the
Company&#146;s financial results and market capitalization relative to the peer companies. The change was the first increase to Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s salary since November&nbsp;2011. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Performance-Based Cash Bonuses. </B>The Compensation Committee establishes target performance-based cash bonus awards on an
annual basis to provide the executive officers with the opportunity to earn compensation for achieving the Company&#146;s annual performance goals. Mr.&nbsp;Cook participates in the same performance-based cash bonus program as the other executive
officers. The target and maximum bonus levels for the executive officers increased in February 2014 to 200% and 400%, respectively, of each officer&#146;s base salary. Because these changes were made mid-year, the increases were phased in for 2014
and applied on a pro-rata basis between the first quarter and the next three quarters of 2014. That is, a target and maximum of 100% and 200%, respectively, applied to each executive&#146;s base salary that was in effect at the end of the first
quarter, and a target and maximum of 200% and 400%, respectively, applied to each executive&#146;s base salary that was in effect at the end of the second, third, and fourth quarters of 2014. Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; and Mr.&nbsp;Maestri&#146;s bonus
opportunities were pro-rated based on the time they served on the executive team during the year. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">In deciding to
increase the bonus opportunities for the executive officers, the Compensation Committee considered the officers&#146; total cash compensation opportunities compared to the total cash compensation opportunities for executives at peer companies, as
well as the Company&#146;s financial results and market capitalization relative to peer companies. At approximately 9%, the target bonuses for the executive </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 34 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">
officers other than Mr.&nbsp;Cook continue to represent a relatively small percentage of each executive&#146;s total target compensation, given the Company&#146;s emphasis on long-term equity
awards and the Company&#146;s preference for emphasizing long-term shareholder value creation over annual operating results. In addition, the Company has no long-term cash bonus program. All long-term incentives are delivered through equity awards.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Performance Criteria.</B> Performance criteria used to determine the annual bonuses for the named executive
officers were net sales and operating income as determined in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. These criteria were chosen because they reflect commonly recognized measures of overall company performance and are associated
with shareholder value creation. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Performance Goals.</B> Performance goals are set at target and maximum levels
based on objectives in the Company&#146;s internal business plan. The target and maximum net sales performance goals for 2014 were set approximately 5% and 6% higher, respectively, than the target and maximum net sales performance goals approved
under the Company&#146;s 2013 bonus program. The target and maximum operating income performance goals for 2014 were set approximately 4% and 6% higher, respectively, than the target and maximum operating income performance goals approved under the
Company&#146;s 2013 bonus program. The Compensation Committee believed that significant leadership efforts would be required to achieve the 2014 performance goals. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The table below shows the target and maximum goals and the Company&#146;s actual performance for 2014. Actual net sales and
operating income for 2014 were both 7% higher than the Company&#146;s net sales and operating income for 2013. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:18pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt" ALIGN="center">

<TD WIDTH="36%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="4%"></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="3%"></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="13%"></TD>

<TR STYLE="font-size:1pt">
<TD HEIGHT="5"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="12"></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:8pt">
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="10" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; "><I>2014 (in Millions)</I></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-size:1pt">
<TD HEIGHT="5"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="4"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="5" COLSPAN="4"></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; "><B>Performance Criteria</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="right" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; "><B>Target&nbsp;Goal</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="2" ALIGN="right" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; "><B>Maximum&nbsp;Goal</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">173,850</FONT></TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">180,000</FONT></TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>

<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">Operating Income</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">46,805</FONT></TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">50,055</FONT></TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">52,503</FONT></TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial; " COLOR="#333333">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Payout Structure.</B> The payout structure is based on an equal weighting of net sales and
operating income because each measure is considered equally important in the Company&#146;s internal business plan. The performance-based cash bonuses are defined as a percentage of the executive&#146;s base salary, and payouts are interpolated for
achievement of performance between the target and maximum goals. No payout is made relative to a particular performance criterion unless the target performance goal is achieved with respect to that criterion. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">At the end of the year, the Compensation Committee determines the amount of the bonus to be paid to each executive officer by
comparing the Company&#146;s financial results to the performance goals. The Compensation Committee may, in its discretion, reduce (but not increase) the amount of any individual bonus based on Company performance and its subjective assessment of
the officer&#146;s overall performance. In 2014, the Company exceeded the maximum performance goals for both net sales and operating income, and the Compensation Committee determined that no downward adjustments to the bonuses would be made based on
Company or individual performance. As a result, the Compensation Committee awarded each named executive officer his or her maximum bonus opportunity for 2014. </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 35 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Executive Perquisites </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The named executive officers are employed at will. As explained above, based on the Company&#146;s philosophy that its executive
compensation program should be simple and directly linked to performance, the compensation program for the named executive officers does not include any change in control payments or gross-up of excise taxes that may be imposed in connection with a
change in control; pensions or supplemental executive retirement benefits; supplemental health or insurance benefits; long-term cash bonuses; retirement acceleration for equity awards; or dividend or dividend equivalent payments on unvested RSUs.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">In addition, the Company generally does not provide perquisites to its officers that are not available to employees
generally. Although the Company does not consider it to be a perquisite for his benefit, the Company provides home and personal security for Mr.&nbsp;Cook because his personal safety and security are of the utmost importance to the Company and its
shareholders. The Company considers the security measures to be a reasonable and necessary expense for the benefit of the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
 COLOR="#333333"><B>Angela Ahrendts </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Angela Ahrendts joined the Company on May&nbsp;1, 2014 as Senior Vice
President, Retail and Online Stores. Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts previously served as the CEO of Burberry and is an internationally renowned leader. During her tenure at Burberry, she led the company through a period of phenomenal growth in which the
company&#146;s market capitalization more than doubled. The recruitment of Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts provided an extraordinary addition to the Company&#146;s executive team with the experience and ability to lead both the retail and online businesses.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">In determining her transition package, the Compensation Committee considered Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; compensation
arrangement at Burberry and the amounts that she was expected to receive in future years. At the time, Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts was among the highest paid executives in the UK and held unvested Burberry equity awards with a value of approximately $37
million. She also received cash and perquisites from Burberry that exceeded $5 million annually, which was significantly higher than the cash opportunities provided to the Company&#146;s executive officers. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Compensation Committee also considered the Company&#146;s executive compensation program and the design changes that it was
evaluating. In addition, the Compensation Committee received advice from its then-current independent compensation consultant, Frederic W. Cook&nbsp;&amp; Co., Inc. (&#147;F.W. Cook&#148;), and from outside legal counsel with expertise in executive
compensation matters. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The elements of Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; transition package are discussed below. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Make Whole RSUs.</B> Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts received an RSU award with a value of $37 million to compensate her for her unvested
Burberry equity awards (&#147;Make Whole RSUs&#148;). Because the Make Whole RSUs were intended to replace her Burberry awards, the vesting dates and the percentage of the Make Whole RSUs vesting on each date were structured to correspond to the
Burberry awards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>New Hire RSUs.</B> Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts also received a new hire RSU award with a value of $33
million (&#147;New Hire RSUs&#148;). The New Hire RSUs were intended to encourage Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts to join the Company and to provide her with a meaningful equity stake in the Company. The New Hire RSUs align with the Company&#146;s emphasis on
equity awards over cash compensation and include performance-based vesting conditions on a substantial portion of the awards. </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 36 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Similar to the equity awards granted to other executive officers in March 2014, 40%
of the total grant date value of the New Hire RSUs is delivered in the form of performance-based RSUs that vest solely based on the Company&#146;s TSR performance. The remaining 60% of the grant date value is delivered in time-based RSUs. The
time-based RSUs are scheduled to vest in three annual installments commencing on May&nbsp;1, 2015, which is the anniversary of Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; start date, subject to Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; continued employment with the Company through the
applicable vesting date. The performance-based RSUs are scheduled to vest annually commencing May&nbsp;1, 2015, subject to Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; continued employment with the Company through the applicable vesting date and satisfaction of
performance conditions for the three performance periods beginning May&nbsp;1, 2014 and ending April&nbsp;30, 2015;&nbsp;April&nbsp;30, 2016; and April&nbsp;30, 2017, respectively. The payout structure and other terms of the performance-based RSUs
are the same as the 2014 annual awards granted to other executive officers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Cash Compensation.</B> Similar to the
Company&#146;s executive officers other than Mr.&nbsp;Cook, Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts receives an annual salary of $1 million, and she was eligible to participate in the Company&#146;s performance-based cash bonus program for executive officers on a
pro-rata basis calculated from her start date. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts also received a hire-on bonus of $500,000, which was
intended to offset some of the cash compensation that Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts was scheduled to receive at Burberry. A pro-rata portion of the hire-on bonus is subject to forfeiture if, within 12 months of her start date, the Company terminates
Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; employment for cause or if she voluntarily terminates employment other than for good reason. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Relocation Expenses.</B> Because Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts resided in the UK, the Compensation Committee approved a relocation package
for her and her family to move closer to the Company&#146;s headquarters. As is common for relocation packages of this nature, the package included full reimbursement for any taxable payments related to the relocation. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Severance.</B> The Company does not generally enter into severance arrangements with executive officers. However, because
Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts was not otherwise expected to have left Burberry, the Company agreed to a cash severance arrangement that was intended to provide her with limited protection within the first three years of employment. If the Company terminates
Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; employment other than for cause or if she resigns for good reason during this period, the Company will pay her as severance, in a single lump sum, the amount of her final base salary for the remainder of the three-year
period. Under this arrangement, the severance value declines to zero by May&nbsp;1, 2017. Consistent with the treatment of the other executive officers, the Company has not entered into, nor does it expect to enter into, any other cash severance
arrangements with Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Luca Maestri </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Effective May&nbsp;29, 2014, the Company appointed Luca Maestri as Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, succeeding
Peter Oppenheimer. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>RSU Awards.</B> On October&nbsp;7, 2013, as part of the Company&#146;s annual review and RSU
grant process, the Compensation Committee awarded Mr.&nbsp;Maestri time-based RSUs with a grant date value of $7 million. The award took place prior to Mr.&nbsp;Maestri&#146;s promotion, when he served as the Company&#146;s Vice President and
Corporate Controller. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Subsequently, in connection with his appointment as Chief Financial Officer on May&nbsp;29,
2014, the Compensation Committee awarded Mr.&nbsp;Maestri a promotion RSU award with a total grant date value of </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 37 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">
$4.3 million (&#147;Promotion RSUs&#148;). When determining the value of the Promotion RSUs, the Compensation Committee considered the RSU grant date value of $20 million awarded to other
executive officers on March&nbsp;3, 2014 and decided to award Mr.&nbsp;Maestri a comparable award for the portion of the year he was expected to serve as Chief Financial Officer, after taking into consideration the value of the $7 million award he
received in October 2013. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Similar to the equity awards granted to other executive officers in March 2014, 40% of the
total grant date value of the Promotion RSUs is delivered in the form of performance-based RSUs that vest solely based on the Company&#146;s TSR performance. The remaining 60% of the grant date value is delivered in time-based RSUs. The time-based
RSUs are scheduled to vest in three annual installments commencing on May&nbsp;29, 2016, which is the second anniversary of Mr.&nbsp;Maestri&#146;s promotion date, subject to his continued employment with the Company through the applicable vesting
date. The performance-based awards are scheduled to vest annually commencing October&nbsp;1, 2015, subject to Mr.&nbsp;Maestri&#146;s continued employment with the Company through the applicable vesting date and satisfaction of performance
conditions for the two performance periods beginning on his promotion date, May&nbsp;29, 2014, and ending September&nbsp;26, 2015 and September&nbsp;24, 2016, respectively. Both performance period end dates coincide with the performance period end
dates for the performance awards granted to the other executives in 2014. The payout structure and other terms of the performance-based RSUs are the same as the 2014 annual awards granted to other executive officers. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Cash Compensation.</B> Similar to the Company&#146;s executive officers other than Mr.&nbsp;Cook, Mr.&nbsp;Maestri receives an
annual salary of $1 million effective from his promotion date. He also participated in the Company&#146;s performance-based cash bonus program for executive officers on a pro-rata basis calculated from his promotion date, and he participated in the
Company&#146;s other bonus programs offered to Vice Presidents of the Company until his promotion date. Vice Presidents are able to participate in the Company&#146;s Vice President Annual Bonus Plan (&#147;Annual Bonus Plan&#148;) and Vice
President&nbsp;&amp; Director Quarterly Bonus Plan (&#147;Quarterly Bonus Plan&#148;). The annual and quarterly goals for the bonus plans offered to Vice Presidents are based on the Company&#146;s net sales and operating income and are established
by the Compensation Committee, at its discretion, based on the Company&#146;s internal business plan. The Company&#146;s performance exceeded the performance goals established under the plans; as a result, Mr.&nbsp;Maestri earned a pro-rated payout
at the maximum amount for each plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Relocation Expenses.</B> Because Mr.&nbsp;Maestri resided outside of
California prior to joining the Company in March 2013, he received a relocation package for him and his family to move closer to the Company&#146;s headquarters. Mr.&nbsp;Maestri received a typical relocation package offered by the Company. Further,
as is common for relocation packages of this nature, the package included full reimbursement for any taxable payments related to the relocation. A portion of these expenses was incurred in 2014. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Governance and Other Considerations </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Tax Deductibility of Compensation Expense. </B>Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code (the &#147;Code&#148;) places a
$1 million limit on the amount of compensation the Company can deduct in any one year for compensation paid to the chief executive officer and the three most highly-compensated executive officers employed by the Company at the end of the year (other
than the Company&#146;s chief financial officer). However, the $1 million deduction limit generally does not apply to compensation that is performance-based and provided under a shareholder-approved plan. While the Compensation Committee considers
the deductibility of awards as one factor in determining executive compensation, the Compensation </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 38 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">
Committee also looks at other factors in making its decisions, as noted above, and retains the flexibility to grant awards it determines to be consistent with the Company&#146;s goal for its
executive compensation program even if the award is not deductible by the Company for tax purposes. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">In general, the
Company&#146;s performance-based cash bonuses have been designed to qualify for tax deductibility because they are paid based on achievement of pre-determined performance goals established by the Compensation Committee pursuant to its equity
incentive plans. However, because the redesign of the executive compensation program resulted in mid-year changes to the payout structure, the exclusion from the deduction limit likely does not apply for the performance-based cash bonuses for 2014.
The Company intends for the exclusion to apply in subsequent years. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">As a result of the modification of
Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s 2011 RSU award to add pre-determined performance criteria,&nbsp;the tranches of the award subject to performance criteria with measurement periods that begin after the June&nbsp;21, 2013 modification are expected to qualify for
tax deductibility. As a result, the Company expects the exclusion from the deduction limit to apply to the 280,000 performance-based RSUs that vested on August&nbsp;24, 2014. In addition, the performance-based RSU awards granted to other executive
officers starting in 2015 are also expected to qualify for tax deductibility under Section&nbsp;162(m). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The
Company&#146;s&nbsp;RSU awards&nbsp;with only time-based vesting requirements, which now represent only a portion of the equity awards granted to executive officers, do not qualify for tax deductibility under Section&nbsp;162(m) to the extent the $1
million limit is&nbsp;exceeded. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Clawback of RSU Awards. </B>The named executive officers&#146; RSU awards are
granted under the Company&#146;s standard RSU agreements. These agreements require an employee to deliver or otherwise repay to the Company any shares or other amount that may be paid in respect of an RSU award in the event the employee commits a
felony, engages in a breach of confidentiality, commits an act of theft, embezzlement or fraud, or materially breaches any agreement with the Company. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Prohibition on Hedging and Short Sales.</B> The Company prohibits short sales and transactions in derivatives of Company
securities, including hedging transactions, for all directors and officers of the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Stock Ownership
Guidelines.</B> Under the Company&#146;s stock ownership guidelines, Mr.&nbsp;Cook is expected to own shares of Company common stock that have a value equal to ten times his base salary. This stock ownership guideline is generally greater than
levels at other Fortune 100 companies. Although Mr.&nbsp;Cook was required to satisfy the stock ownership guideline within five years of its implementation in 2012, he already owns shares with a value significantly in excess of the guideline. Other
named executive officers are expected to own shares that have a value equal to three times their base salary. This guideline is required to be satisfied by the later of February&nbsp;6, 2018 or within five years after an officer first becomes
subject to the guideline. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Risk Considerations.</B> The Compensation Committee considers, in establishing and
reviewing the executive compensation program, whether the program encourages unnecessary or excessive risk taking and has concluded that it does not. See the section entitled &#147;Board Oversight of Risk Management&#148; above for an additional
discussion of risk considerations. </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 39 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:Arial"><FONT COLOR="#197bd7"><B><A NAME="toc774604_26"></A>Executive Compensation Tables </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><B><A NAME="toc774604_27"></A>Summary Compensation Table&#151;2014, 2013, and 2012 </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The following table shows information regarding compensation of each named executive officer for 2014, 2013 and 2012, except in
the cases of Mr.&nbsp;Maestri and Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts, who were not named executive officers in 2013 and 2012. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:18pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The grant date fair value for time-based RSUs is measured based on the closing fair market value of the Company&#146;s common stock on
the date of grant. The grant date fair value for performance-based RSUs is calculated based on a Monte-Carlo valuation of each award on the date of grant, determined under FASB Topic 718. Assuming the highest level of performance is achieved under
the applicable performance conditions, the maximum possible value of the performance-based RSUs granted to the named executive officers in 2014, using the grant date fair value, is: (i)&nbsp;in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Maestri, $3,468,490; (ii)&nbsp;in
the case of Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts, $26,401,560; (iii)&nbsp;in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Cue, $16,001,386; (iv)&nbsp;and in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Williams, $16,001,386. For a description of the assumptions and
</FONT></P></TD>

annual bonuses are based on the performance of the Company and the individual executive relative to pre-determined objectives for the year. The target and maximum amounts for each named executive officer&#146;s 2014 bonus opportunity are shown in
the table entitled &#147;Grants of Plan-Based Awards&#151;2014.&#148; In 2014, the Company exceeded the maximum performance goals for both net sales and operating income, and the Compensation Committee determined that no downward adjustments to the
bonuses would be made based on Company or individual performance. As a result, the Compensation Committee awarded each named executive officer his or her maximum bonus opportunity for 2014. Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; and Mr.&nbsp;Maestri&#146;s bonus
opportunities were pro-rated based on their time on the executive team in the year. Mr.&nbsp;Maestri also participated in the Company&#146;s other bonus programs offered to Vice Presidents of the Company until his promotion date. </FONT></P></TD>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><B>Compensation of Named Executive Officers </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The table entitled &#147;Summary Compensation Table&#151;2014, 2013, and 2012&#148; above quantifies the value of the different
forms of compensation of each named executive officer for services rendered during 2014, 2013, and 2012. The primary elements of each named executive officer&#146;s total compensation shown in the table are base salary, an annual bonus, and
long-term equity awards consisting of time-based and performance-based RSUs. Named executive officers also received the other benefits listed in Column (g)&nbsp;of the table entitled &#147;Summary Compensation Table&#151;2014, 2013, and 2012,&#148;
as further described in the footnotes to the table. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The table entitled &#147;Summary Compensation Table&#151;2014,
2013, and 2012&#148; should be read in conjunction with the following tables and narrative descriptions. The table entitled &#147;Grants of Plan-Based Awards&#151;2014&#148; and the accompanying description provide information regarding the bonus
opportunities awarded to named executive officers in 2014. The tables entitled &#147;Outstanding Equity Awards at 2014 Year-End&#148; and &#147;Option Exercises and Stock Vested&#151;2014&#148; provide further information on the named executive
officers&#146; potential realizable value and actual value realized with respect to their equity awards. </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The grant date fair value for time-based RSUs is measured based on the closing fair market value of the Company&#146;s common stock on
the date of grant. The grant date fair value for performance-based RSUs is calculated based on a Monte-Carlo valuation of each award on the date of grant, determined under FASB ASC Topic 718, incorporating the following assumptions: </FONT></P></TD>

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Company used its historical stock prices as the basis for the volatility assumptions. The risk-free interest rates were based on
U.S. Treasury rates in effect at the time of grant. The expected term was based on the time remaining in the applicable performance period on each grant date. </FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

Significant Accounting Policies found in Part II, Item&nbsp;8, &#147;Financial Statements and Supplementary Data&#148; in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements in the Annual Report. </FONT></P></TD>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Mr.&nbsp;Maestri participated in the Company&#146;s performance-based cash bonus program for executive officers on a pro-rata basis
calculated from his promotion date, and he participated in the Company&#146;s other bonus programs offered to Vice Presidents of the Company until his promotion date. The amount shown in Column (c)&nbsp;reflects a pro-rated threshold bonus amount of
$76,456 under the Quarterly Bonus Plan. The amount shown in Column (d)&nbsp;reflects pro-rated target bonus amounts of $133,798 under the Quarterly Bonus Plan, $38,228 under the Annual Plan and $670,330 under the performance-based cash program for
executive officers. The amount shown in Column (e)&nbsp;reflects pro-rated maximum bonus amounts of $191,140 under the Quarterly Bonus Plan, $76,456 under the Annual Plan and $1,340,659 under the performance-based cash bonus program for executive
officers. </FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><B>Description of Plan-Based Awards </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Non-Equity Incentive Plan Awards.</B> Each of the &#147;Non-Equity Incentive Plan Awards&#148; shown in the table entitled
&#147;Grants of Plan-Based Awards&#151;2014&#148; was granted under the&nbsp;Company&#146;s&nbsp;2003 Employee Stock Plan (the &#147;2003 Plan&#148;), which provided flexibility to grant non-equity&nbsp;incentive awards (i.e., cash bonus
opportunities), as well as equity awards. The material terms of the 2014 non-equity incentive awards are described under &#147;Executive Compensation&#151;Compensation Discussion and Analysis&#148; in the section entitled &#147;The Role of Cash
Compensation.&#148;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>All Other Stock Awards.</B> Column (f)&nbsp;of the table entitled &#147;Grants of Plan-Based
Awards&#151;2014&#148; shows awards of time-based and performance-based RSUs granted to the named executive officers in 2014. Each of these awards was granted under, and is&nbsp;subject to, the terms of the 2014 Plan. The Compensation Committee
administers the 2014 Plan.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Time-Based RSUs.</B> The remaining time-based RSUs granted to Mr.&nbsp;Maestri on
October&nbsp;7, 2013 are scheduled to vest in seven semi-annual installments commencing on&nbsp;October 15, 2014, and the time-based RSUs granted on May&nbsp;29, 2014 are scheduled to vest in three annual installments commencing on May&nbsp;29,
2016. The Make Whole RSUs granted to Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts are scheduled to vest in various amounts over several dates through June&nbsp;14, 2018. The New Hire RSUs granted to Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts are scheduled to vest in three annual installments
commencing on May&nbsp;1, 2015. The time-based RSUs granted to Mr.&nbsp;Cue and Mr.&nbsp;Williams are scheduled to vest in three annual installments commencing on April&nbsp;1, 2016. In each case, vesting is contingent on the officer&#146;s
continued employment with the Company through the applicable vesting date. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Performance-Based RSUs. </B>The
&#147;target&#148; number of performance-based RSUs is shown in the table entitled &#147;Grants of Plan-Based Awards&#151;2014.&#148; 7,959 performance-based RSUs granted to Mr.&nbsp;Maestri are scheduled to vest on October&nbsp;1, 2015, and 7,749
performance-based RSUs are scheduled to vest on October&nbsp;1, 2016, in each case, subject to his continued employment with the Company through the applicable vesting date and satisfaction of performance conditions for the performance periods
beginning on May&nbsp;29, 2014 and ending on September&nbsp;26, 2015 and September&nbsp;24, 2016, respectively. 40,719 performance-based RSUs granted to Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts are scheduled to vest on May&nbsp;1, 2015; 40,173 performance-based RSUs are
scheduled to vest on May&nbsp;1, 2016; and 40,229 performance-based RSUs are scheduled to vest on May&nbsp;1, 2017, in each case, subject to her continued employment with the </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 44 </FONT></P>

Company through the applicable vesting date and satisfaction of performance conditions for the performance periods beginning on May&nbsp;1, 2014 and ending on April&nbsp;30,
2015;&nbsp;April&nbsp;30, 2016; and April&nbsp;30, 2017, respectively. 46,382 performance-based RSUs granted to Mr.&nbsp;Cue and Mr.&nbsp;Williams are scheduled to vest on October&nbsp;1, 2015, and 44,912 performance-based RSUs are scheduled to vest
on October&nbsp;1, 2016, in each case, subject to their continued employment with the Company through the applicable vesting date and satisfaction of performance conditions for the performance periods beginning on September&nbsp;29, 2013 and ending
on September&nbsp;26, 2015 and September&nbsp;24, 2016, respectively. As described under &#147;Executive Compensation&#151;Compensation Discussion and Analysis,&#148; in each case, between 0% and 200% of the performance-based RSUs vest depending on
the Company&#146;s relative TSR compared to the other companies in the S&amp;P 500 over the relevant performance period, with 100%&nbsp;of the target RSUs vesting if the Company&#146;s relative TSR is at the 55th&nbsp;percentile. Regardless of the
Company&#146;s performance, if the Company&#146;s TSR for the performance period is negative, the number of RSUs that vest is capped at 100% of the target number of RSUs. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><B><A NAME="toc774604_29"></A>Outstanding Equity Awards at 2014 Year-End </B></P>

named executive officers as of September&nbsp;27, 2014. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:18pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">(11)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The time-based RSUs subject to this award are scheduled to vest in three annual installments commencing on April&nbsp;1, 2016, assuming
that the officer continues to be employed with the Company through the applicable vesting date. 46,382 performance-based RSUs subject to this award are scheduled to vest on October&nbsp;1, 2015, and 44,912 performance-based RSUs subject to this
award are scheduled to vest on October&nbsp;1, 2016, in each case, assuming that the officer continues to be employed with the Company through the applicable vesting date and satisfaction of applicable performance conditions. </FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">(12)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The remaining RSUs subject to this award are scheduled to vest in their entirety on March&nbsp;21, 2016, assuming that the officer
continues to be employed with the Company through the applicable vesting date. </FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 46 </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The dollar amounts shown in Column&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;above for stock awards are determined by multiplying the number of shares that vested
by the per-share closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock on the vesting date and any dividend equivalents attributable to such shares. </FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><B><A NAME="toc774604_31"></A>Potential Payments Upon Termination or Change in Control </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">As described under &#147;Executive Compensation&#151;Compensation Discussion and Analysis&#148; in the section entitled
&#147;Angela Ahrendts,&#148; Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts received a cash severance arrangement when she joined the Company. Within the first three years of her start date, if the Company terminates Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; employment other than for
&#147;Cause&#148; or if she resigns for &#147;Good Reason,&#148; the Company will pay her as severance, in a single lump sum, the amount of her final base salary for the remainder of the three-year period. Under this arrangement, the severance value
declines to zero by May&nbsp;1, 2017.&nbsp;In addition, the vesting of Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; Make Whole RSUs is accelerated if the Company terminates her employment other than for &#147;Cause&#148; or if she resigns for &#147;Good Reason.&#148;
Had Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; employment terminated on September&nbsp;26, 2014, the last business day of the Company&#146;s fiscal year ended September&nbsp;27, 2014, the estimated amount that she would have been entitled to under the cash severance
arrangement would have been $2,589,041, and the estimated amount she would have been entitled to under the Make Whole RSUs would have been $32,646,728. &#147;Cause&#148; and &#147;Good Reason&#148; are defined in Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; offer
letter. &#147;Cause&#148; generally means an act of fraud or material dishonesty; gross misconduct; failure to follow the lawful direction of the CEO or Board; failure to perform material duties for the Company; or material breach of a Company
policy. &#147;Good Reason&#148; generally means a material change in duties or responsibilities; a change in the reporting structure such that Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts no longer reports to the CEO; a material change in primary work location; or a breach by
the Company of any of its material commitments in connection with Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts&#146; employment. </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 47 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Aside from the arrangement with Ms.&nbsp;Ahrendts, which was offered to encourage her
to join the Company, the Company does not generally enter into severance arrangements with its named executive officers, and the Company does not maintain any plans&nbsp;or arrangements that provide for other named executive officers to receive cash
severance or other cash payments in connection with a termination of the officer&#146;s employment with the Company or a change in control of the Company. Further, none of the equity awards granted to the named executive officers under the
Company&#146;s equity incentive plans provide for acceleration in connection with a change in control. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Equity
Acceleration upon Death or Disability </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Time-Based RSUs.</B> Time-based RSU awards provide for partial
accelerated vesting upon the disability of the award recipient. In August 2014, the Compensation Committee amended all time-based RSUs held by all employees in the Company, including the time-based RSUs held by members of the executive team, to
provide for full accelerated vesting upon death. Prior to this amendment, the awards provided for partial accelerated vesting upon death. The Compensation Committee intends to include this term in time-based RSUs it grants in the future. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><B>Performance-Based RSUs.</B> Performance-based RSU awards provide for partial vesting upon the death or disability of the award
recipient, with the number of shares determined at the end of the performance period, based on actual performance. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The
following table lists the named executive officers and the estimated amounts they would have become entitled to under the terms of all outstanding RSU awards granted to them&nbsp;had their employment terminated due to either (i)&nbsp;death or
(ii)&nbsp;disability on September&nbsp;26, 2014, the last business day of the Company&#146;s fiscal year ended September&nbsp;27, 2014. The estimated payments for the performance-based RSUs are based on performance to date as of September&nbsp;26,
2014. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:18pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" ALIGN="center">

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:15pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><B><A NAME="toc774604_33"></A>AUDIT AND FINANCE COMMITTEE REPORT </B></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:18pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P><div style="width:100%;margin-left:5%; margin-right:5%;background-color:#efefef;padding-top:2pt;padding-bottom:3pt">
<P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-top:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333"><I>The following is the report of the Audit and Finance Committee with respect to
the Company&#146;s audited financial statements for the year ended September&nbsp;27, 2014. The information contained in this report shall not be deemed &#147;soliciting material&#148; or otherwise considered &#147;filed&#148; with the SEC, and such
information shall not be incorporated by reference into any future filing under the Securities Act or the Exchange Act except to the extent that the Company specifically incorporates such information by reference in such filing.</I> </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Audit and Finance Committee consists of four members: Drs. Levinson and Sugar and
Mr.&nbsp;Iger and Ms.&nbsp;Wagner. All of the members are independent directors under the NASDAQ, NYSE, and SEC audit committee structure and membership requirements. The Audit and Finance Committee has certain duties and powers as described in its
written charter adopted by the Board. A copy of the charter can be found on the Company&#146;s website at </FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Arial" COLOR="#197bd7"><U>investor.apple.com/corporate-governance.cfm</U></FONT><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Arial" COLOR="#333333">. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Audit and Finance Committee is
responsible primarily for assisting the Board in fulfilling its oversight and monitoring responsibility of reviewing the financial information that will be provided to shareholders and others, appointing the independent registered public accounting
firm, reviewing the services performed by the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm and internal audit department, evaluating the Company&#146;s accounting policies and the system of internal controls established by management
and the Board, reviewing significant financial transactions, and overseeing enterprise risk management. The Audit and Finance Committee does not itself prepare financial statements or perform audits, and its members are not auditors or certifiers of
the Company&#146;s financial statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">In fulfilling its oversight responsibility
of appointing and reviewing the services performed by the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm, the Audit and Finance Committee carefully reviews the policies and procedures for the engagement of the independent registered
public accounting firm, including the scope of the audit, audit fees, auditor independence matters and the extent to which the independent registered public accounting firm may be retained to perform non-audit services. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Company maintains an auditor independence policy that, among other things, prohibits the
Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm from performing non-financial consulting services, such as information technology consulting and internal audit services. This policy mandates that the Audit and Finance Committee approve
in advance the audit and permissible non-audit services to be performed by the independent registered public accounting firm and the related budget, and that the Audit and Finance Committee be provided with quarterly reporting on actual spending.
This policy also mandates that the Company may not enter into engagements with the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm for non-audit services without the express pre-approval of the Audit and Finance Committee. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Audit and Finance Committee has reviewed and discussed the audited
financial statements for the year ended September&nbsp;27, 2014 with the Company&#146;s management and Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP, the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm (&#147;EY&#148;). The Audit and Finance Committee has
also discussed with EY the matters required to be discussed by Auditing Standard No.&nbsp;16, &#147;Communications with Audit Committees&#148; issued by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (&#147;PCAOB&#148;). </FONT></P></div>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 50 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <div style="width:100%;margin-left:5%; margin-right:5%;background-color:#efefef;padding-top:2pt;padding-bottom:3pt">
<P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-top:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Audit and Finance Committee also has received and reviewed the written
disclosures and the letter from EY required by applicable requirements of the PCAOB regarding EY&#146;s communications with the Audit and Finance Committee concerning independence, and has discussed with EY its independence from the Company.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Based on the reviews and discussions referred to above, the Audit and Finance
Committee recommended to the Board that the financial statements referred to above be included in the Company&#146;s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended September&nbsp;27, 2014. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Members of the Audit and Finance Committee </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Ron Sugar (Chair) | Bob Iger | Art Levinson | Sue Wagner </FONT></P></div>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 51 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:15pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><B><A NAME="toc774604_34"></A>PROPOSALS </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:Arial"><B>Overview of Proposals </B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">This Proxy
Statement contains six proposals requiring shareholder action: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:10pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Proposal No.&nbsp;1 requests the election of seven directors to the Board. </FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:10pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Proposal No.&nbsp;2 requests the ratification of the appointment of Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP as the Company&#146;s independent
registered public accounting firm for 2015. </FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:10pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Proposal No.&nbsp;3 requests that shareholders vote on an advisory resolution approving the Company&#146;s executive compensation.
</FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:10pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Proposal No.&nbsp;4 requests that shareholders approve amendments to the Apple Inc. Employee Stock Purchase Plan. </FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:10pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT COLOR="#333333">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="justify" STYLE="font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Proposals No.&nbsp;5 and No.&nbsp;6 are shareholder proposals. </FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Each proposal is discussed in more detail in the pages that follow. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:Arial"><FONT COLOR="#197bd7"><B><A NAME="toc774604_35"></A>Proposal No.&nbsp;1 &#150; Election of Directors </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Board has nominated directors Cook, Gore, Iger, Jung, Levinson, Sugar, and Wagner to be elected to serve until the next annual
meeting of shareholders and until their successors are duly elected and qualified. Mr.&nbsp;Drexler, who has served on the Board since 1999, has notified the Board of his intention to retire at the end of his current term. The Board has not yet
nominated an individual to fill the vacancy that will be created by Mr.&nbsp;Drexler&#146;s departure from the Board. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">At the Annual Meeting, proxies cannot be voted for a greater number of individuals than the seven nominees named in this Proxy
Statement. Holders of proxies solicited by this Proxy Statement will vote the proxies received by them as directed on the proxy card or, if no direction is made, for the election of the Board&#146;s seven nominees. If any nominee is unable or
declines to serve as a director at the time of the Annual Meeting, the proxy holders may vote for any nominee designated by the present Board to fill the vacancy. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#197bd7"><I>The Board recommends that shareholders vote FOR the election of directors Cook, Gore, Iger, Jung, Levinson, Sugar, and Wagner.
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:18pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P><div style="width:100%;margin-left:5%; margin-right:5%;background-color:#efefef;padding-top:2pt;padding-bottom:3pt">
<P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-top:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><B>Vote Required </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Company has implemented majority voting in uncontested elections of
directors. Accordingly, the Company&#146;s bylaws provide that in an uncontested election of directors the affirmative vote of (i)&nbsp;a majority of the shares present or represented by proxy and voting at the Annual Meeting and (ii)&nbsp;a
majority of the shares required to constitute a quorum is required to elect a director. </FONT></P></div>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:9pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#333333">Apple Inc. |
Proxy Statement | 52 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:Arial"><FONT COLOR="#197bd7"><B><A NAME="toc774604_36"></A>Proposal No.&nbsp;2 &#150; Ratification of Appointment of Independent
Registered Public Accounting Firm </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">The Audit Committee has re-appointed Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP as the
Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm and as auditors of the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements for 2015. Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP has served as the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm
since February 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT COLOR="#333333">At the Annual Meeting, the shareholders are being asked to ratify the appointment of
Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP as the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm for 2015. In the event of a negative vote on such ratification, the Audit Committee will reconsider its selection. Even if this appointment is ratified,
the Audit Committee, in its discretion, may direct the appointment of a different independent registered public accounting firm at any time during the year if the Audit Committee determines that such a change would be in the best interests of the
Company and its shareholders. Representatives of Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP are expected to be present at the Annual Meeting, will have an opportunity to make a statement if they desire to do so, and will be available to respond to questions.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><B>Fees Paid to Auditors </B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:Arial" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
 COLOR="#333333">The following table shows the fees accrued or paid to the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm for the years ended September&nbsp;27, 2014 and September&nbsp;28, 2013. </FONT></P>
